title: 105_s2147
content: The text introduces a new section in the Internal Revenue Code to provide a deduction for married couples to eliminate the marriage penalty. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code allows a deduction for joint returns to address the marriage penalty. The deduction is based on the lower qualified earned income spouse, with the applicable percentage decreasing as modified adjusted gross income exceeds $50,000. The modified adjusted gross income is determined after specific adjustments and without considering certain deductions. The $50,000 deduction amount is subject to a cost-of-living adjustment for taxable years after 2002. The term 'qualified earned income' is defined as the excess of the spouse's earned income for the taxable year over certain deductions. The amount is rounded to the next lowest multiple of $2,000 if not already a multiple. The term 'earned income' for tax purposes excludes certain types of income, such as pension payments, annuities, distributions from retirement plans, deferred compensation, and income earned by one spouse for services performed for the other spouse. The tax code amendments include a deduction for two-earner married couples and a marriage penalty reduction in the earned income credit phaseout. Income for any taxable year shall be reduced by an amount equal to the deduction allowed under section 222. The tax code amendments include a deduction for married couples to eliminate the marriage penalty and a cross-reference. The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1998. Additionally, there is a deduction for health insurance costs for self-employed individuals. SEC. 2. DEDUCTION FOR HEALTH INSURANCE COSTS FOR SELF-EMPLOYED INDIVIDUALS. An individual who is an employee can deduct 100 percent of medical insurance costs for themselves, spouse, and dependents. Effective for taxable years after December 31, 1998.
